com.soa.message.script

Interface Exchange


  • public interface Exchange

    Represents an exchange in a scripted environment. An exchange is one invocation of an operation. It may have a request and a reply or only a request based on its exchange pattern as described in the WSDL document. From an exchange you can get information about the call being made such as which service is being called, which operation, which binding is being used (if from an external client), and which endpoint is being called (if from an external client).

    You can also get direct access to the input, output, and fault messages associated with the exchange at the moment however it is recommended that the message variables defined within the process should be used instead. In fact, the output and fault messages of the calling exchange of a process will not even be populated during process execution.

    You can gain access to the calling exchange of a process as follows: 

        exchange = processContext.getCreatingExchange();

    From there you can get information about the exchange as follows: 

        auditLog.debug("service is " + exchange.getServiceName());
    auditLog.debug("operation is " + exchange.getOperationName());
    auditLog.debug("endpoint is " + exchange.getEndpointName());

    Exchanges can have properties associated with them. A property can be any type of Java object identified by a unique string name. These can be useful for passing context information to/from policy handlers that are used when processing the exchange. You can access an exchange's property as follows: 

        prop1 = exchange.getProperty("prop1");

    You can create or change a property with: 

        exchange.setProperty("prop1", "myPropertyValue");

      Returns a URI identifying the type of binding used in the exchange.

      Returns the name of the endpoint being called.

    • Method Detail

      • getExchangeID

        java.lang.String getExchangeID()
        Returns a unique identifier for the exchange between the two parties.
        Returns:
        Unique identifier of the exchange.

      • getProperty

        java.lang.Object getProperty(java.lang.String name)
        Returns the property with the given name.
        Parameters:
        name - Name of the property.
        Returns:
        Object holding the value of the requested property, null if none found.

      • setProperty

        void setProperty(java.lang.String name,
                 java.lang.Object property)
        Adds or replaces a property.
        Parameters:
        name - Name of the property.
        property - Value of the property.

      • getPropertyNames

        java.util.Set getPropertyNames()
        Returns the names of the properties associated with the context. Changes made to the Set are reflected in the context, so if a name is removed from the Set, the property is removed from the context. Names cannot be added however.
        Returns:
        Set of String property names.

      • getServiceName

        javax.xml.namespace.QName getServiceName()
        Returns the name of the service being invoked.
        Returns:
        QName of the service.

      • getEndpointName

        java.lang.String getEndpointName()
        Returns the name of the endpoint being called.
        Returns:
        Name of the endpoint.

      • getBinding

        java.lang.String getBinding()
        Returns a URI identifying the type of binding used in the exchange. This is typically the namespace of the WSDL binding extension.
        Returns:
        String URI of the binding type. May be null.

      • getInterfaceName

        javax.xml.namespace.QName getInterfaceName()
        Returns the name of the interface being called.
        Returns:
        Name of the interface.

      • getOperationName

        java.lang.String getOperationName()
        Returns the name of the operation being invoked.
        Returns:
        Name of the operation.

      • getStatus

        int getStatus()
        Returns the status of the exchange (0=ACTIVE, 1=DONE, 2=ERROR).
        Returns:
        Status of the exchange (0=ACTIVE, 1=DONE, 2=ERROR).

      • getInMessage

        Message getInMessage()
        Returns the in message that is part of the exchange (if any).
        Returns:
        Message holding information about the message, null if none associated with the exchange.

      • getOutMessage

        Message getOutMessage()
        Returns the out message that is part of the exchange (if any).
        Returns:
        Message holding information about the message, null if none associated with the exchange.

      • getFaultMessage

        Message getFaultMessage()
        Returns the fault message that is part of the exchange (if any).
        Returns:
        Message holding information about the message, null if none associated with the exchange.

      • getPattern

        java.lang.String getPattern()
        Returns the message exchange pattern to be used.
        Returns:
        Message exchange pattern to be used, i.e., IN_OUT, IN_ONLY.

      • isAsync

        boolean isAsync()
        Returns whether the exchange should be completed asynchronously or not.
        Returns:
        True if asynchronous, false if synchronous.

      • setServiceName

        void setServiceName(javax.xml.namespace.QName name)
        Changes the name of the service to invoke. This should only be used for exchanges that have not already begun.
        Parameters:
        name - QName of the service to invoke.

      • setServiceName

        void setServiceName(java.lang.String name)
        Changes the name of the service to invoke. This should only be used for exchanges that have not already begun.
        Parameters:
        name - String representation of the QName of the service to invoke.

      • setEndpointName

        void setEndpointName(java.lang.String name)
        Changes the name of the endpoint to invoke. This should only be used for exchanges that have not already begun.
        Parameters:
        name - Name of the endpoint to invoke.

      • setInterfaceName

        void setInterfaceName(javax.xml.namespace.QName name)
        Changes the name of the interface to call. This should only be used for exchanges that have not already begun.
        Parameters:
        name - QName of the interface to call.

        Parameters:
        name - Name of the operation to invoke.

      • setInMessage

           throws com.digev.fw.exception.GException
        Changes the message used as input to the exchange.
        Parameters:
        msg - Message to be used as input.
        Throws:
        com.digev.fw.exception.GException - Thrown if unable to set the message, most likely due to an input message already existing in the exchange.
